content:
• Monday, January 14, 2019
  • IMMU

    Immunomedics says shutdown won't slow cancer drug decision

    • Immunomedics (NASDAQ:IMMU) says it's progressing with the FDA and doesn't expect a delayed decision on its cancer drug around the government shutdown, Bloomberg reports.
    • The company's treatment -- sacituzumab govitecan -- has a PDUFA date set this Friday, and would mark Immunomedics' first product on the market.
    • Shares are up 3.4% on relatively heavy after-hours trading.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:40 PM
  • JCP

    JCPenney sets leadership plans, says CFO search is 'well under way'

    • Discussing a series of leadership changes, JCPenney (NYSE:JCP) notes searches are "well under way" for a new chief financial officer and chief merchant officer among other key positions it's filling.
    • The retailer plans a "cross-functional executive team that merges the talents and perspectives of new and existing industry leaders to focus on the needs of the value-based consumer and position the company for growth."
    • Mike Robbins will be made executive VP and chief stores and supply chain officer, effective Jan. 21. He's currently executive VP of private brands and supply chain.
    • Truett Horne of McKinsey & Co. will join as chief transformation officer, reported directly to CEO Jill Soltau.
    • Meanwhile, it's looking for the CFO (a spot for which it has "many compelling candidates"); chief merchant (to lead merchandising efforts across categories); a chief customer officer (to grow traffic, engagement and retention); a senior VP of Planning and Allocation (to lead goal-setting for sales, inventory and replenishment); and a principal accounting officer (CAO and Controller Andrew Drexler is leaving the company March 31).
    • Shares fell 1.5% during the regular session and are up 1.5% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:29 PM | 44 Comments
  • EXEL

    Exelixis +4% after FDA approves liver cancer drug

    • Exelixis (NASDAQ:EXEL) +3.9% after-hours following news that the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved its Cabometyx tablets for patients with hepatocellular carcinoma - the most common form of liver cancer - who previously were treated with another drug.
    • EXEL says the FDA’s approval was based on results from a Phase 3 pivotal trial in which Cabometyx demonstrated a statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvement in overall survival vs. placebo.
    • Last November, EXEL partner Ipsen received approval from the European Commission for Cabometyx tablets as a monotherapy for HCC in adults who previously were treated with sorafenib.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:02 PM | 16 Comments
  • TMUS

    T-Mobile confirms its 5G network is up, awaiting compatible phones

    • T-Mobile (NASDAQ:TMUS) has quietly confirmed that it has an active 5G network in 30 cities, Light Reading reports, after questioning the carrier about its pledge to do so by the end of 2018.
    • But the news is quiet because the company says it won't offer commercial services on the network until 5G smartphones are available -- likely the beginning of next year.
    • Without more details, it's hard to know whether the networks are robust or only a few sites as proof of concept, Mike Dano notes.
    • But its timeline is closely enough aligned with efforts from key rivals AT&T and Verizon, with particular service launch dates still vague.
    • T-Mobile is the only major carrier planning to launch its 5G services on 600 MHz spectrum, ideal for long ranges but not optimized for data speed like the 28 GHz and 39 GHz frequencies (which will also be part of T-Mobile's approach).
    • Shares fell 1.6% during the regular session and are up 1.5% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:01 PM | 2 Comments
  • BGFV

    After hours movers and shakers

    • Gainers: BGFV +10.9%. PLAY +6.1%. FTNW +5.2%. AZN +2.0%. FTR +1.9%.
    • Losers: ALNY -3.5%. ARR -2.6%. VIV -2.1%. FIT -1.4%. PFPT -0.9%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:37 PM | 3 Comments
  • AGI

    Alamos Gold posts record gold production for 2018, up 18% Y/Y

    • Alamos Gold (NYSE:AGI) +2.1% after-hours on news it produced a record 505K oz. of gold in 2018, an 18% Y/Y increase, driven by strong performances from Mulatos and Island Gold.
    • Q4 production totaled 125.6K oz. of gold, up 4.4% Y/Y, reflecting a stronger performance from Young-Davidson and record production from Island Gold; Q4 sales were a record 131,164 oz. of gold at an average realized price of $1,244/oz. for $163M in revenues.
    • For 2019, AGI guides for production of 480K-520K oz. of gold, consistent with 2018 production, at all-in sustaining cost guidance of $920-$960/oz., down 5% from revised 2018 guidance of $990/oz.
    • AGI forecasts annual gold production of ~500K oz./year in 2019 and 2020, increasing to 600K-plus oz. in 2021, reflecting a full year of production from Kirazli.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:22 PM | 10 Comments
  • STML

    Stemline readies 6.6M-share stock offering; shares down 4% after hours

    • Stemline Therapeutics (NASDAQ:STML) is down 4% after hours following its announced 6.6M-share stock offering. Price and terms have yet to be announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:52 PM | 9 Comments
  • ARR

    ARMOUR Residential -2.1% after 5M-share offering launches

    • ARMOUR Residential REIT (NYSE:ARR) sinks 2.1% in after-hours trading after announcing a 5M-share common stock offering.
    • Greenshoe option of up to 750K additional shares.
    • Intends to use proceeds to acquire additional target assets as market conditions warrant and for general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM | 17 Comments
  • PLAY

    Dave & Buster's rallies after strong guidance

    • Dave & Buster's Entertainment (NASDAQ:PLAY) provides a guidance update. The company says it expects to report that FQ4 comparable store sales increased 1.8% to 2.5%. For the full year, revenue is anticipated to land in a range of $1.259B to $1.263B. Net income for the full year is seen coming in at $112M to $114M and EBITDA of $276M to $278M is anticipated.
    • "Opening new stores with outstanding returns remains a key priority and we are maintaining our plan to open 15 to 16 new stores in fiscal 2019," says D&B's CEO Brian Jenkins.
    • PLAY +2.6% AH.
    • Source: Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:34 PM
  • EVBG

    Everbridge readies stock offering

    • Everbridge (NASDAQ:EVBG) launches a $125M public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Shares are down a fraction after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:29 PM
  • BGNE

    BeiGene's zanubrutinib a Breakthrough Therapy for aggressive type of NHL

    • The FDA designates BeiGene's (NASDAQ:BGNE) BTK inhibitor zanubrutinib a Breakthrough Therapy for the treatment of adult patients with mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) who have received at least one prior line of therapy.
    • MCL, an aggressive form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), represents ~6% of new NHL cases.
    • Breakthrough Therapy status provides for more intensive guidance from the FDA on development, the involvement of more senior agency personnel and a rolling review of the marketing application.
    • Shares are up 2% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:27 PM
  • XLRN

    Acceleron initiates $200M stock offering

    • Acceleron Pharma (NASDAQ:XLRN) launches a $200M public offering of common stock. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Shares are up 1% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM | 3 Comments
  • ALNY

    Alnylam launches 5M-share stock offering

    • Alnylam Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:ALNY) commences a public offering of 5M shares of common stock. Price and terms have yet to be announced.
    • Shares are up 2% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:15 PM
  • BPTH

    Bio-Path readies stock offering; shares down 5% after hours

    • Bio-Path Holdings (NASDAQ:BPTH) is down 5% after hours in response to its announced stock offering. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM
  • TSLA

    Tesla in reverse amid Detroit Auto Show buzz

    • Shares of Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) are down 3.71% in a move some traders are attributing to the news coming out of the Detroit Auto Show.
    • Yesterday, Ford (F +2%) Chairman Bill Ford outlined the automaker's $11B investment in electric vehicles by 2022 with plans to have 40 hybrid and fully electric vehicles in its model lineup. Tomorrow is also the big announcement on the Ford alliance with Volkswagen that is sure to include electrification and mobility collaboration.
    • There is also continued buzz in the Motor City over the all-electric Cadillac coming from General Motors (GM +1.4%), as well as talk on Nissan's (OTCPK:NSANY) expanding EV plans for the Infiniti brand in 2021.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM | 584 Comments
  • BABA

    Alibaba trades down as president discusses slowing Chinese economy

    • Alibaba (NYSE:BABA) is dipping anew, now down 1.7%, after some cautious optimism from its president included acknowledgment that China's consumer market continues to decelerate.
    • “China has slowed down,” J. Michael Evans says at the National Retail Federation show. “As a $13 trillion economy, it would be quite unusual if it could continue to grow at 7% or 8%.”
    • But he still expects China to become the world's largest economy over the next 10 years, led by consumption as a percentage of GDP.
    • It's a market that "requires patience," Evans says. "But if you think about where the country is going in the long-term…The future I think looks very good, notwithstanding some troubling headwinds.”
     
     
     
     
    | 3:56 PM | 15 Comments
  • XPO

    XPO Logistics cut at KeyBanc on BBFM competition, European exposure

    • XPO Logistics (XPO -4.5%) slumps after KeyBanc downgrades shares to Sector Weight from Overweight, citing the increasingly competitive big and bulky final mile market along with macroeconomic weakness in Europe, where the company has high exposure.
    • XPO, with its first-mover advantage, has a 7% share of the BBFM market, but competition from well-established and well-capitalized firms could slow its growth from to the mid-to-high teens to low-double digits, says KeyBanc's Todd Fowler.
    • The firm thinks the hiring of a CFO with public company exposure and an acquisition track record could be a catalyst, but "final mile has been viewed as a key differentiator, with increased competition a potential, incremental negative, while ongoing European headwinds imply higher growth in remaining segments to achieve EBITDA targets."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:54 PM
  • NVS

    Novartis in crosshairs of Dutch health minister over Lutathera price

    • Dutch Health Minister Bruno Bruins is accusing Novartis (NVS -1.1%) of "gaming" Orphan Drug status to hike the price of Lutathera (lutetium I77 dotatate), a radiotherapy it acquired in its $2.9B takeout of Advanced Accelerator Applications a year ago. He say the Orphan Drug program was designed to stimulate the development of new medicines, not registering a relatively old experimental therapy. He plans to raise the issue with European authorities.
    • According to DutchNews, a full course of treatment (four infusions) costs €90,000. The company counters that hospitals pay a fraction of that, €16,000 (€4,000 per infusion), for house-made versions, adding “the price of Lutathera was carefully considered and based on the benefit the treatment provides to patients, healthcare systems and society at large. It is priced comparably to other existing therapies approved for this patient population."
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 1 Comment
  • NOC

    Northrop Grumman upgraded at Credit Suisse after 2018 correction

    • Northrop Grumman (NOC +2.4%) is higher after Credit Suisse upgrades shares to Outperform from Neutral with a $311 price target, citing valuation after the stock tumbled 21% in 2018.
    • "With 2018’s market correction, NOC now has one of the most well supported valuations among the defense primes," writes Credit Suisse analyst Robert Spingarn.
    • NOC's cutting-edge tech focus is more in line with the direction the U.S. military is moving than it has been in the past, Spingarn says, citing the company’s Common Infrared Countermeasures program as an example of a relatively small but significant high tech product expected to enjoy a revenue ramp over the next several years.
    • Among other projects that likely will lead to strong revenue growth in coming years are the F-35 aircraft, on which NOC is a key supplier, and the Air Force’s B-21 Raider stealth bomber, which Spingarn says is one of NOC’s “most compelling longer-term growth opportunities.”
     
     
     
     
    | 3:21 PM
  • BMY

    Congressmen urge DOJ to scrutinize Bristol-Myers Squibb - Celgene tie-up

    • U.S. Representatives Peter Welch (D-VT At large) and Francis Rooney (R-FL 19th District) have sent a letter to the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice urging a "careful examination" of Bristol-Myers Squibb's (BMY +0.7%) $74B takeout of Celgene (CELG +0.1%).
    • The lawmakers cite the potential negative impact on competition and drug prices as the reasons for their suggested scrutiny.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM | 28 Comments
  • BOXL

    Microcaps mostly among tech movers

    • Gainers: Boxlight Corporation (NASDAQ:BOXL) +23%. Identiv (NASDAQ:INVE) +22%. USA Technologies (NASDAQ:USAT) +21%. Borqs Technologies (NASDAQ:BRQS) +16%. Gridsum Holding (NASDAQ:GSUM) +11%.
    • Losers: Inpixon (NASDAQ:INPX) -26%. Summit Wireless Technologies (WISA) -16%. Internet Gold - Golden Lines (NASDAQ:IGLD) -16%. CooTek (NYSE:CTK) -16%. Autohome (NYSE:ATHM) -14%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:04 PM
  • CHK

    Nat gas futures soar 16% following new weather forecast

    • Natural gas futures surge, settling +15.9% to $3.591/MMBtu, following weekend weather and new forecasts calling for some rather cold weather through the end of the month.
    • The February Henry Hub futures contract hit a session peak at $3.539/MMBtu, its highest level since Dec. 27.
    • "The forecast has turned significantly colder," says Jacob Meisel, chief weather analyst at Bespoke Weather Services. "It’s really the magnitude of the cold and the confidence in severity longer term that’s changed over the weekend."
    • With natural gas inventories still 15% below the five-year average, Barclays sees room for higher prices even if weather normalizes during the rest of winter, and forecasts Henry Hub prices to average $3.51/MMBtu in Q1 and $2.92/MMBtu for the full year.
    • "The market had seemingly written off a return to cold weather during the downturn of the last six weeks or so, and today’s price action is a good reminder that there’s still a lot of winter left," says Barclays' VP for global gas and energy Sam Phillips.
    • Most gas-focused equities show solid gains: CHK +2.2%, EQT +2.1%, COG +1.5%, RRC +2.4%, AR +2.2%, GPOR +1%, SWN +0.2%.
    • ETFs: UNG, UGAZ, DGAZ, BOIL, GASL, FCG, KOLD, UNL, GASX, GAZB
     
     
     
     
    | 2:59 PM | 110 Comments
  • NEM

    Newmont’s Goldcorp deal needs 'drastic surgery' to pay off, analyst says

    • The merged company created by combining Newmont Mining (NEM -8.8%) and Goldcorp (GG +8%) will have the world’s largest production and reserve base, and the kind of liquidity and diversified assets required to attract institutional investors, yet NEM "has some difficult times ahead, with drastic surgery needed at Goldcorp," says Maison Placements Canada analyst John Ing.
    • "In the short term and medium term, the deal is not good for Newmont," Ing tells Bloomberg.
    • GG's recent share price weakness "underscores the market’s perception of both Goldcorp’s assets and operating conditions," writes Morgan Stanley's Piyush Sood. "With Newmont’s management acquiring operational control, execution concerns at the new assets will slowly lift, but Newmont will have to reassure investors that the assets are indeed NAV accretive and won’t lead to another negative reset in expectations."
    • But Scotiabank analysts say the deal is positive for NEM, "because it establishes it as the world’s leading gold producer with a deal that is accretive on nearly all key metrics."
    • Barclays analyst Matthew Murphy praises the "fairly compelling rationale" for the deal because GG was trading for just 0.97x his estimate of net asset value before the announcement while NEM fetched ~1.5x NAV.
    • "Long term, Goldcorp investors may be disappointed, even with the 17% premium offered, as the company’s long promised (and long delayed) recovery was supposed to begin this year," writes J.P. Morgan's John Bridges, who thinks GG was 65% undervalued vs. NEM’s 15%.
    • "The industry clearly feels that it needs to do something to become more relevant. One way to do that is just to become bigger," says RBC's James Bell. "The question becomes now, will there be a domino effect?"
     
     
     
     
    | 2:48 PM | 38 Comments
  • CGC

    NY grants hemp license to Canopy Growth; shares up 11%

    • The State of New York has granted a license to Canopy Growth (CGC +11.2%) allowing it to process and produce hemp. The company plans to invest $100M - 150M in the state to establish operations capable of producing "tons of hemp" annually.
    • Related ticers: (TLRY +6.7%)(CRON +2%)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:06 PM | 109 Comments
  • VIA

    Viacom reportedly eyes potential sale of majority stake in China ops

    • Viacom (VIA +1.7%, VIAB +2%) is higher today following yesterday's WSJ report that the company is in talks to sell a majority stake in some China operations.
    • Such a move would follow other major U.S. multinational divestments from China, and reflect troubles trying to scale business there recently.
    • Viacom could sell control of its channel brands like MTV and Nickelodeon in a move that would mirror a similar Viacom JV with Reliance in india.
    • Viacom's also reportedly in talks to acquire streaming service Tubi TV.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:02 PM | 1 Comment
  • PED

    PEDEVCO and Midstates Petroleum among Energy/Materials gainers; Camber Energy and ION Geophysical among losers

    | 2:00 PM
  • INST

    Instructure -8.5% as still-bullish Raymond James downgrades

    • Instructure (NYSE:INST) has slid 8.5% to a three-week low after drawing a downgrade from bull Raymond James.
    • The firm cut its rating to Outperform, from Strong Buy.
    • Volume is heavy and nearing its daily average already.
    • Analyst Brian Peterson is keeping his $45 target, though, which today is implying 21% upside.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:58 PM
  • OXBR

    Oxbridge Re Holdings leads financial gainers; Loop Industries and 360 Finance among losers

    • Losers: eXp World Holdings (NASDAQ:EXPI) -9%. Loop Industries (NASDAQ:LOOP) -8%. 360 Finance (NASDAQ:QFIN) -7%. X Financial (NYSE:XYF) -6%. PPDAI Group (NYSE:PPDF) -6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:56 PM | 2 Comments
  • MBOT

    VVUS, RNN, MBOT & PCG among midday movers

    • Gainers: Microbot Medical (NASDAQ:MBOT) +224%. PEDEVCO (NYSEMKT:PED) +41%. Renmin Tianli Group (NASDAQ:ABAC-OLD) +37%.
    • VIVUS (NASDAQ:VVUS) +23%. USA Technologies (NASDAQ:USAT) +21%. Gannett (NYSE:GCI) +20%. Boxlight Corporation (NASDAQ:BOXL) +21%. Borqs Technologies (NASDAQ:BRQS) +17%. Rexahn Pharmaceuticals (NYSEMKT:RNN) +17%. Co-Diagnostics (NASDAQ:CODX) +16%.

CooTek (NYSE:CTK) -14%. ToughBuilt Industries (NASDAQ:TBLT) -14%. Autohome (NYSE:ATHM) -13%. Stein Mart (NASDAQ:SMRT) -13%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:53 PM
  • ZAYO

    Zayo briefly spikes on report of offer at $30/share or more

    • Shares in Zayo Group (ZAYO -1.2%) spiked briefly after a report by CTFN that the company received an offer in excess of $30/share, but quickly retreated.
    • The stock was up as much as 1.7% immediately following the news this hour, but are already back in the red for the day, sitting at $25.78 vs. that reported $30-plus offer from a private-equity consortium.
    • That offer followed an original rejected offer but the bid's been complicated by debt-market volatility, according to the report.
    • The company's been on a slide in the past half-year, with shares down 33.7% over the past six months. They're still up 7% over the past week.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:20 PM | 2 Comments
  • UNH

    UnitedHealth reports tomorrow; shares up 1%

    • UnitedHealth Group (UNH +0.7%) kicks off the healthcare Q4 earnings season tomorrow morning before the open. Consensus view is non-GAAP EPS of $3.21 on revenues of $59.7B.
    • 2019 guidance (will be updated in press release): revenues: $243B - 245B; non-GAAP EPS: $14.40 - 14.70.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:11 PM | 1 Comment
  • ABAC-OLD

    Lululemon Athletica and New Age Beverages among consumer gainers; Pyxus International leads losers

    • Gainers: Renmin Tianli Group (NASDAQ:ABAC-OLD) +28%. Lululemon Athletica (NASDAQ:LULU) +9%. YETI Holdings (NYSE:YETI) +9%. New Age Beverages (NASDAQ:NBEV) +9%. China Automotive Systems (NASDAQ:CAAS) +7%.
    • Losers: Pyxus International (NYSE:PYX) -9%. At Home Group (NASDAQ:HOME) -8%. Cryoport (NASDAQ:CYRX) -7%. Tuniu (NASDAQ:TOUR) -6%. Celsius Holdings (NASDAQ:CELH) -5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:02 PM | 2 Comments
  • MED

    Medifast sees 2018 EPS of $4.45 - 4.50

    • In its January corporate presentation (slide #33), Medifast (MED -0.9%) expects 2018 revenue of $492.5M - 497.5M compared to consensus of $498.0M. EPS forecast is $4.45 - 4.50 versus consensus of $4.52.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:01 PM
  • C

    Citi perks up as volatility moderates

    • Citigroup (NYSE:C) revives 3.8% after its chief financial officer says the trading environment started to improve this month.
    • "Volatility has somewhat moderated and both equity prices and yields have shown signs of stabilization," CFO John Gerspach told reporters on a call.
    • The bank reported earlier that FICC revenue sank 39% in Q4 vs. Q3 as market volatility kept investors on the sidelines. Its shares had declined as much as 1.7% soon after the market opened.
    • Banks, overall, perked up after an initial decline Monday morning. The Financial Select Sector SPDR ETF (NYSEARCA:XLF) is up about 0.6% at midday.
    • Citi's peers are also in the green: Morgan Stanley (MS +0.8%), Bank of America (BAC +0.8%), JPMorgan (JPM +0.7%), Goldman Sachs (GS +0.5%), and Wells Fargo (WFC +0.3%).
    • Previously: Citigroup revenue misses on ugly quarter for fixed income (Jan. 14)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:59 AM | 4 Comments
  • LILAK

    Reuters: Liberty Latin America bidding for Millicom; shares jump

    • Liberty Latin America (NASDAQ:LILAK) is jumping, up 3%, following a Reuters report that the company has approached Millicom (NASDAQ:TIGO) with a takeover bid.
    • Millicom's Nasdaq shares are up 8.1%.
    • John Malone's wireless/cable operator has been in talks with Millicom (focused on Latin America and Africa) for weeks, according to the news service.
    • Millicom last week updated guidance as it began trading common shares on Nasdaq.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM | 18 Comments
  • CODX

    Co-Diagnostics up 15% on CoPrimers presentation

    • Thinly traded nano cap Co-Diagnostics (CODX +15.3%) is up on a healthy 21x surge in volume, albeit on turnover of only 446K shares. Today, a company scientist is presenting research on the SNP genotyping and multiplex capabilities of CoPrimers at the International Plant and Genome Conference in San Diego.
    • On the working capital front, at the end of September 2018, it had $2.2M in cash and equivalents while operations consumed $3.1M during the first three quarters of the year.
    • In August 2018, it filed a prospectus for a $25M mixed shelf offering.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:48 AM
  • CBLI

    Cleveland BioLabs up 34%

    • Ultra-thinly traded nano cap Cleveland BioLabs (CBLI +33.8%) is up on double normal volume, albeit on turnover of only 17K shares, on no particular news.
    • At the end of September 2018, it $5.3M in quick assets while operations consumed $3.4M during the first three quarters of the year.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:39 AM
  • WDC

    WDC on worst day since October as Evercore frets dividend

    • Western Digital (NYSE:WDC) has slipped 7.6% in its worst day since October, and touched a two-week low, after Evercore cut its rating to Underperform on worries about a dividend cut.
    • Free cash flow is tracking to about $2.35/share or lower this year, and "combined with $11b in gross debt ($6.5b net debt), we see clear risk to the current annual dividend of $2.00," analyst C.J. Muse writes. (h/t Bloomberg)
    • Muse is "hard pressed" to see the dividend sustainable under current conditions. The firm's cut its price target to $30 from $35, implying 19% further downside.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:27 AM | 24 Comments
  • RNN

    Rexahn up 16% ahead of updated RX-3117 data

    • Thinly traded nano cap Rexahn Pharmaceuticals (RNN +16.3%) is up on nearly four times normal volume. On Friday, it will present updated data from a Phase 2a clinical trial evaluating the combination of RX-3117 and Celgene's Abraxane (paclitaxel/nab-paclitaxel) in first-line pancreatic cancer at the ASCO GI Cancers Symposium in San Francisco.
    • In October 2018, it reported a 29% (n=4/14) response rate and 86% (n=12/14) disease control rate.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:23 AM
  • TEUM

    Shutdown spurs Pareteum to extend tender for iPass

    • Pareteum (TEUM +0.7%) has extended a tender offer for all outstanding shares of iPass (IPAS +2.8%) due to the government shutdown.
    • That's caused delays with Pareteum's registration statement.
    • The tender is now set to expire at 5 p.m. New York City time on Feb. 12.
    • As of the end of Friday, some 4,949,254 shares were validly tendered, about 58.7% of outstanding iPass shares.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:22 AM | 2 Comments
  • PCG

    PG&E bonds plunge, spreads widen on Chapter 11 plan

    • PG&E (PCG -48.8%) plunges by ~50% after unveiling a plan to seek bankruptcy protection amid mountainous liabilities linked to California wildfires.
    • Nearly all of PG&E’s ~$18B of bonds were trading sharply lower, sending their yields to record highs, Reuters reports, citing data from MarketAxess.
    • The drops are particularly large among its nearest maturities, with bonds maturing in October 2020 and May 2021 both falling by more than 7 points in price, with their yield spreads surging to 12.65 and 11.16 percentage points, respectively, much higher than the 4.5 percentage point average spread of high-yield notes over Treasuries.
    • Eight of the top 10 most-traded U.S. corporate bonds this morning belong to PG&E, with the most actively traded a $3B note coming due in March 2034, according to MarketAxess.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:15 AM | 76 Comments
  • AMGN

    FDA Ad Com approaches for Amgen's osteoporosis med romosozumab

    • The FDA's Bone, Reproductive and Urologic Drugs Advisory Committee will meet on Wednesday, January 16, to review and discuss Amgen's (AMGN -1.4%) resubmitted marketing application seeking approval for EVENITY (romosozumab) injection for the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women at high risk for fracture.
    • The company received a CRL in July 2017 citing the need to further evaluate the cardiovascular (CV) risk.
    • Due to the safety signal, Amgen is now proposing the narrower indication (originally osteoporosis in postmenopausal women), a Boxed Warning and a Warning and Precaution for CV risk. Efficacy is not in question.
    • FDA briefing doc
    • Errata to FDA briefing doc

  • AAPL

    Wedbush talks Apple M&A targets and XR price cuts

    • Wedbush analyst Dan Ives calls Apple's (NASDAQ:AAPL) pricing hubris on iPhone XR the major factor in the "earnings debacle" for December. Ives say while iPhone XS continues to be focused on premium price points, the linchpin on the upgrade cycle was XR within the China region representing ~20% of all iPhones in the window of an upgrade opportunity. "To put numbers around this, with ~750 million active iPhones worldwide based on our estimates and 350 million of those in a window of an upgrade opportunity over the next 12 to 18 months, we estimate between 60 million to 70 million of iPhones slated to be upgraded/new purchases are out of the key China region," he notes.
    • Ives thinks Apple should "aggressively" cut prices in China on XR and pull forward an estimated is roughly 15M to 20M iPhones sales that would otherwise be sitting idle or be lost to competition.
    • He also recommends that Apple make a major content acquisition to drive the services flywheel. "In a nutshell, ultimately with $250 billion+ of potential dry M&A powder now is the time for Apple to rip off the band-aid and finally do significant content M&A with the landscape ripe otherwise it will be a major strategic mistake in our opinion that will haunt the company for years to come, with content being the rocket fuel in the services engine that is currently missing in the portfolio," he writes. On that M&A wildcard, Ives and team call A24, Lionsgate and Sony Pictues (NYSE:SNE) "higher probability" targets and sees Viacom (NYSE:VIA)/CBS (NYSE:CBS) and MGM Studios as "medium" probability targets. Netflix, Disney and various videogame publishers are called "low" probability targets.
    • Wedbush keeps an Outperform rating on Apple and price target of $200.
    • AAPL -0.76% premarket to $151.10.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:26 AM | 34 Comments
